instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1708: What is A1708? A1708 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2017, 2016 with EMC 3164, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00840, 820-00875..
definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H_CPU: What is PPBUS_G3H_CPU? PPBUS_G3H_CPU is the .
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.D6905: What is D6905? Diode sitting between PPBUS_G3H/PP18V5 charger voltage and PP3V42_G3H power supply input on very old Macbooks(before 2011), can die and cause PP3V42_G3H to be missing and have no input voltage. .
definitions.C7050: What is C7050? Capacitor between current sense lines on ISL6259 chip for battery current sensing, you should measure around 2.202 ohms across this. Often when the resistance across this capacitor is higher it is because one of the current sense resistors going to the ISL6259 chip has failed. When current sensing resistors between the shunt resistor and the ISL6259 power IC have failed the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No power 5v 0amp
threads.message:
Good morning, 

No signs of liquid damage. When I received the board, only one of the USB-C Ports was working, I replaced the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> with a correct C00 version and now both ports work. Prior to replacing the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> was at 2.1v, not it's at 4.8v. However, the device still does not turn on. 

With the battery removed:

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>  0.1mV
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S5G</SIGNAL> 0.0
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> 4.83v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_CPU</SIGNAL> 40mV
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 40.3mV
<SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_XA_USBX</SIGNAL>-<SIGNAL>CA_VBUS_CONN</SIGNAL> 5.1v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_LDO3V</SIGNAL> - 0.6mV

I reflowed <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> since it seemed like this would be the problem area, but still no dice. Any help appreciated. Thank you

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No power 5v 0amp
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> 4.83v"
Big problem there; you have important overvoltage on <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> power rail.
Check the exact values of the resistor in the feedback network (<RESISTOR>R6993</RESISTOR>-97); don't forget R/<CAPACITOR>C6994</CAPACITOR>.
Also check all traces in that area; pay atention to XW6995.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No power 5v 0amp
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R6993</RESISTOR> - 30.6 mV
<RESISTOR>R6994</RESISTOR> - 7.8 V (both sides)
<RESISTOR>R6995</RESISTOR> - 3.4V (right side)
<RESISTOR>R6995</RESISTOR> - 1.1V (left side)
<RESISTOR>R6996</RESISTOR> -30.6 mV (right side) 
<RESISTOR>R6996</RESISTOR> - 1.013 V (left side
<RESISTOR>R6997</RESISTOR> - 3.4V (both sides)

<CAPACITOR>C6993</CAPACITOR> - 4.8V
<CAPACITOR>C6994</CAPACITOR> - V3V3G3H__BST_R 7.7V
<CAPACITOR>C6994</CAPACITOR> - <SIGNAL>V3V3G3H_SW</SIGNAL> 3.4V

Can't seem to find XW6995

as always, thank you for your help. Trying to figure this out.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No power 5v 0amp
threads.message:
<DIODE>D6905</DIODE> was the culprit, PPDCIN wasn't making contact, now that it's fixed I get 3.4v on 3V3G3H, still stuck at 5.191v 0a


Updated numbers With the battery removed:

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 0.0mV
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S5G</SIGNAL> 0.0
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.4V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_CPU</SIGNAL> 40mV
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_S5</SIGNAL> 46.8 mV
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> -50mV
<SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_XA_USBX</SIGNAL>-<SIGNAL>CA_VBUS_CONN</SIGNAL> 5.1v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_LDO3V</SIGNAL> - 0.6mV

I noticed the USB-C port that wasn't working before switching the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip is reading <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> at 2.9-3.0v little lower than the other USB-C port.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No power 5v 0amp
threads.message:
So you never had 4.83V at <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>?
Please, post accurate information; is your interest to save time.
You couldn't get higher voltage there with bad contact on <DIODE>D6905</DIODE>.

Both USB-C ports must have same behavior.
If not, compare diode mode readings between both channels around <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.
Start with their LDO lines.

Check diode mode to ground at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and all big coils.
Remove F7000 and check <CAPACITOR>C7050</CAPACITOR> voltage.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No power 5v 0amp
threads.message:
All mentioned LDOs get correct voltage?
Be aware, 1V1 LDO should appear on the powered port only.

You've forgot diode mode on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and big coils.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No power 5v 0amp
threads.message:
I'm showing <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at .403V (diode mode)

Putting F7000 back on 
1V1 LDO is showing .1 mV - .2mV back and forth on both sides at the same time.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No power 5v 0amp
threads.message:
We still don't know if you get correct LDOs voltage on <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.
Each one has 4 LDO lines.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No power 5v 0amp
threads.message:
I'm going to be honest man, I don't know what exactly you're asking or telling me to look at.

What do you mean we don't know if I get the correct LDO's voltage on the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips? I gave you the reading I found, not sure how I'm suppose to spot check that. I realize each one has 4 LDO lines, I believe i've provided all of them to you.

I understand you can't just tell me the answer as there can be many answers, but at the same time I joined this forum because I don't know how to find these things. I'm asking for guidance so I can learn.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No power 5v 0amp
threads.message:
"DIODE Readings (no power obviously)"
I supposed that you've posted diode readings indeed.
BTW, for the future, don't write "V" after diode readings; avoid any misunderstood.

Please, post now voltage on these LDOs.
Let see if you get all them good.
Be aware, 1V1 LDO must appear on the powered port only.

Also, did you check diode mode on the big coils?
